title: While the government does nothing about gun violence, CEOs are filling the void (opinion)
text:
Peter Georgescu is Chairman Emeritus of Young & Rubicam and author, most recently, of Capitalists Arise!: End Economic Inequality, Grow the Middle Class, Heal the Nation. The opinions expressed in this commentary are his own.

Walmart's recent decision to pull handguns and certain types of ammunition from its shelves was a brave and socially conscious act. Today, mass shootings and gun violence are among society's most critical issues. Every one of us is a potential victim, simply by being present — in a public space, a classroom, a nightclub or even at work. We need a serious fix and we need it urgently.

As American citizens, we typically look to our government's leaders to act in a situation where our individual and collective safely is so clearly at risk. The government could address the crisis with authority by passing legislation that makes the background checks for gun purchases more rigorous. But, tragically, the government continues to do nothing. Political agendas, special interest groups, lobbyists and campaign contributions all have been put before America's general safely. It feels eerily like the deadlock on legislative efforts to close the wealth gap in this country — it generates much discussion, but little or nothing in the way of new laws.

Without government action, who will step up? The next most-powerful institution in our country: business.

With just over two million employees and a customer base touching vast portions of America, Walmart is a stalwart of commerce. It also sells guns. Walmart could have chosen to do nothing. It could hide behind the government's tragic inaction, but it didn't. Instead, it took a significant step forward.

A couple weeks ago, the Business Roundtable recognized that the separation of business from society was hurting the country. They suggested that the era of shareholder primacy must end, and that business must serve multiple stakeholders, including customers and employees.
